course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Upper-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Virtue and Vice in the Christian Tradtion
course.description: Reciprocal Credit: CHR 319 An examination of the nature of virtue and vice in the history of philosophy and Christian moral theology with special attention given to the tradition of the seven capital vices.

course.name: Science and Faith
course.description: Reciprocal credit: CHR 438. Exploration of the major scientific concepts guiding modern science in relationship to the major faith commitments of the Christian faith as expressed in the gospel and the creeds in an effort to produce constructive dialogue that will mutually inform the two ways of knowing. Concepts explored include cosmology, evolution, quantum physics, and chaos theory; Doctrines explored include: creation, revelation, incarnation, salvation, exaltation, and eschatology as they relate to specific scientific concerns.

course.name: Philosophy of Film
course.description: Reciprocal Credit: CHR 448. An examination of philosophical themes as developed in film with special attention given to existentialism, nihilism, pragmatism, phenomenalism, and postmodernism.

course.name: Philosophy of Religion
course.description: Prerequisite: PHL 240. Reciprocal credit in CHR 450. A study of the philosophical attempt to understand the nature of God and the significance of religion in the life of man. An investigation as to the validity of the claim to a type of knowledge called religious'' and the methods whereby such is gained.''

course.name: External Domestic Study Programs
course.description: All courses and their applications must be defined and approved prior to registering.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their applications must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Independent Study
course.description: Individual research under the guidance of a faculty member(s).

course.name: Senior Seminar
course.description: Functions as a required capstone or exit seminar for majors in the School of Theology and Missions (except Philosophy). Focuses on competencies in the following areas: defining one's mission and values; understanding the church's relationship to contemporary culture and the global context; and academic research and writing. In the final half of the course, the students will present research papers in the theological discipline of their choice. Must be taken during senior year. Majors in the Honors Program must take a 3 hour Senior Seminar.

course.name: Principles of the Physical Sciences
course.description: Introduction to physics and chemistry for non-science majors including their historical, philosophical, and social significance. Exercises are indicative of various scientific methods. Knowledge of basic algebra is assumed. Science credit will not be given after completion of a course in CHE or a PHY course numbered 200 or higher. Three lectures, one 2-hour laboratory/week.

course.name: Earth and Space Science
course.description: Reciprocal credit: GEO 112. Earth science and astronomy: their nature, history, divisions, and relation to other sciences. The physical laws of nature will be examined as they apply to physical geography, meteorology, and astronomy. Three lectures, one 2-hour laboratory/week.

course.name: The World of Water
course.description: Prerequisites: PHY 111 (or higher) or CHE 105 (or higher) This course is a survey of water, its nature and properties, its role in the physical world, and its role in human society. The uses of water by individuals and societies will be addressed. Ramifications and applications range from international geopolitics to designing a water pump system for a well. Cannot be used as an elective toward PHY major/minor.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Lower-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Introduction to Physics
course.description: Prerequisite: MAT 111 and 112, or 116. The first semester involves the study of classical mechanics, wave motion, fluid flow, sound, temperature, and heat. The second involves the study of electricity, magnetism, light, optics, and modern physics. Cannot be used as a PHY Elective toward majors/minors. Three lectures, one 3-hour laboratory/week.

course.name: Introduction to Physics
course.description: Prerequisite: MAT 111 and 112, or 116. The first semester involves the study of classical mechanics, wave motion, fluid flow, sound, temperature, and heat. The second involves the study of electricity, magnetism, light, optics, and modern physics. Cannot be used as a PHY Elective toward majors/minors. Three lectures, one 3-hour laboratory/week.

course.name: University Physics I With Calculus
course.description: Prerequisite to 231: MAT 211. Pre- or Corequisite to 232: MAT 212. The first semester involves the study of classical mechanics, wave motion, fluid flow and sound. The second involves the study of temperature and heat, electricity, magnetism, light and optics. Four lectures, one laboratory/week.

course.name: University Physics II With Calculus
course.description: Prerequisite to 231: MAT 211. Pre- or Corequisite to 232:MAT 212. The first semester involves the study of classical mechanics, wave motion, fluid flow and sound. The second involves the study of temperature and heat, electricity, magnetism, light and optics. Four lectures, one laboratory/week.

course.name: Electrical and Electronic Circuits
course.description: Prerequisite: PHY 232 and MAT 212. Reciprocal credit: EGR 262. See EGR 262 for description.

course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Lower-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Perspectives in Science
course.description: Prerequisite: PHY 111-2. Reciprocal credit: CHE 301. The study of science from a historical and philosophical perspective in an interdisciplinary manner, exploring the complementarity of physical and biological sciences, while addressing relationships to other disciplines such as art, religion, and politics. Examines the role of science in global issues and life issues. Three lecture, 2 lab hours/week.

course.name: Energy, Environment, and Society
course.description: Prerequisite: PHY 111. A non-technical course for the general student presenting a broad view of energy and its relationship to man and the environment. Topics: past and future demands, energy sources, storage and transportation of energy, environmental considerations, conservation, politics, economics, and national policy. Three lectures, 3 lab hours/week.

course.name: University Physics: Modern Physics
course.description: Prerequisite: MAT 212 and PHY 232. An introduction to special relativity, quantum mechanics, atomic, and nuclear physics. The laboratory involves investigations in radioactivity, as well as performing some of the classic experiments of modern physics. Three lectures, one 3-hour lab/week.

course.name: The World of Water
course.description: Prerequisites: PHY 111 or CHE 105 This course is a survey of water, its nature and properties, its role in the physical world, and its role in human society. The uses of water by individuals and societies will be addressed. Ramifications and applications range from international geopolitics to designing a water pump system for a well. Cannot be used as an elective toward PHY major/minor.

course.name: Intermediate Mechanics
course.description: Prerequisite: PHY 232 and MAT 212. Introduction to rectilinear and curvilinear dynamics of particles and rigid bodies; both Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations of mechanics will be developed and applied.

course.name: Intermediate Electricity and Magnetism
course.description: Prerequisites: MAT 212 and PHY 232. Electric and magnetic fields both in media and a vacuum. Maxwell's equations are used to determine electromagnetic fields produced by a variety of charge and current distributions.

course.name: Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
course.description: Prerequisites: MAT 212 and PHY 232. An intermediate survey of heat and thermodynamics including the concepts of temperature and heat, the laws of thermodynamics, thermodynamics potentials, the Maxwell relations and statistical methods applied to the thermodynamics of various states of matter, including gases, liquids, and quantum fluids.

course.name: Introduction to Astrophysics
course.description: Pre-requisite: PHY 232 An introduction to the behaviors of solar systems, stars, and galaxies. Newtonian celestial mechanics, gravitation, simple nuclear physics, and introductory cosmology will be included.

course.name: Mathematical Methods in Physics
course.description: Prerequisites: MAT 213, PHY 232. Special differential equations, complex number analysis, linear algebra, group theory and Fourier analysis applied to advanced topics in physics.

course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Upper-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Upper-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Upper-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Optics and Lasers
course.description: Prerequisites: MAT 213, PHY 232. Analyzes the behavior of electromagnetic radiation, emphasizing geometrical optics and instrumentation. The role of optics in spectroscopic measurements will be highlighted by discussing polarization and diffraction. Includes an introduction to laser physics and operations using systems, including excimer and neodymium-YAG lasers.

course.name: Nuclear Physics
course.description: Prerequisites: MAT 213 and PHY 311. A study of the atomic nucleus, including its constituents, interactions and energies. Radiative processes, angular momentum, and practical applications such as astrophysics, medical physics, energy production, and environmental physics.

course.name: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics
course.description: An introduction to properties of various phases of matter from the macroscopic scale down to the atomic.

course.name: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics
course.description: Pre-requisite: PHY 311 An introduction to properties of various phases of matter from the macroscopic scale down to the atomic. The topics covered in this course will include crystal structure, the reciprocal lattice, structural analysis techniques (wave diffraction), the historical progression and theories of various models of electrical conduction, energy bands, semiconductors, metals, and Fermi surfaces.

course.name: Quantum Mechanics
course.description: Prerequisites: PHY 311 and MAT 314. Fundamental principles of quantum mechanics, methods of calculation, and solutions to Schrodinger's equation. Applications to atomic, molecular, and nuclear physics with an introduction to operator notation. Three lecture hours/week.

course.name: Physics Research
course.description: Prerequisite: PHY 311. Application of a simple piece of original work to include a literature search and summary paper on a topic of current interest in physics. Under faculty supervision, this work may be done off site at a national laboratory or comparable research facility.

course.name: Physics Research
course.description: Prerequisite: PHY 311. Application of a simple piece of original work to include a literature search and summary paper on a topic of current interest in physics. Under faculty supervision, this work may be done off site at a national laboratory or comparable research facility.

course.name: Experimental Physics Laboratory
course.description: Prerequisites: PHY 311 and MAT 213. Modern experimentation, research, data acquisition and analysis. The theory, practice and reporting of research in a scientific format are demonstrated through experiments in atomic, nuclear, solid state, thermodynamics, and optics. One lecture, 4 lab hours/week.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Independent Study
course.description: Individual study under the guidance of a faculty member(s).

course.name: Seminar
course.description: To be used at the discretion of the department.

course.name: Introduction to Political Science
course.description: An introduction to the concepts and concerns of political science: the power relationships among men, between men and the state, and among nations.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Lower-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Politics and Government of the United States
course.description: A study of the development, structure, and operation of our national government.

course.name: International Relations
course.description: A study of the basic concepts of international politics, national power, diplomacy and warfare, and other vital interests of nations.

course.name: Comparative Political Systems
course.description: An analysis of the primary political systems that form the basis of modern nation-states, namely, liberal democratic systems, communist and post-communist systems, and the developing systems of the post-colonial international community. This course does not deal with particular governmental structures.

course.name: Research Methodology
course.description: Research methodologies utilized in political science.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Politics and Film
course.description: The impact of film on the politics and thinking of American society towards concepts such as war, peace, race, regions of the world and political ideas.

course.name: State and Local Government
course.description: A study of the institutions and functions of state and local governments and their relationship to the political process and federalism.

course.name: Political Parties in the United States
course.description: A study of the nature, development, and functioning of political parties in the United States. Attention is given to leaders, issues, and problems of our party system.

course.name: Western Political Thought I
course.description: Great political thinkers in the Western tradition from the Greeks to the 17th Century.

course.name: Western Political Thought II
course.description: Great political thinkers in the Western tradition from the 17th century to the present.

course.name: Contemporary Global Issues
course.description: Current affairs focusing on events and attitudes within the world community with an assessment of their impact on domestic and foreign policy decisions in the U.S. and abroad.

course.name: Politics and Governments of Asia
course.description: A study of Asia in modern times with emphasis on China, Japan, and one additional state selected on the basis of political conditions in Asia at the time of the course.

course.name: Public Administration and Policy Making
course.description: A study of the fourth branch'' of government of the United States with a focus on the development of public policy and its administration. The relationship among the executive, legislative, and judicial branches is also emphasized.

course.name: Early Christian Political Thought
course.description: Reciprocal credit: CHR 331. A study of political thought from the beginning of Christianity to the Reformation.

course.name: International Organizations and Law
course.description: International organizations, both governmental and nongovernmental, as they interact with international community. International law and its development are examined.

course.name: Modern Christian Political Thought
course.description: Reciprocal credit: CHR 335. A study of the various streams of Christian political thought since the Reformation.

course.name: American Political Thought
course.description: The study of American political thought from the colonial times to the present.

course.name: The Judicial Process
course.description: The nature of law, the principal actors in the legal system-police, lawyers, and judges-and their roles in the system as well as the ability of courts to make social policy.

course.name: The United States Congress
course.description: The role of Congress in American government, including congressional elections, representation, the organization of Congress, and policy-making and its interaction with others such as the president, interest groups, the media, and political parties.

course.name: The American Presidency
course.description: A study of the constitutional, institutional and historical development of the presidency with special attention to the selection, roles, and powers of the president and his interaction with other political actors.

course.name: Ethics and Public Policy
course.description: The application of ethical theories to contemporary political issues.

course.name: Christian Political Thought
course.description: A study of political thought from the beginning of Christianity to the present.

course.name: Economic Political Thought
course.description: A study of major economic thinkers regarding the political regulation of the economy.

course.name: Politics of the Developing States
course.description: Developing states referred to as the Third (Fourth) World, including Bangladesh, most of Africa, and parts of SE Asia, beginning with the end of the colonial period.

course.name: Politics of Islam
course.description: The politics of Islamic beliefs such as traditionalism, reformism, and secularism, and their political influence on governments throughout the Islamic world and their relationship with Israel.

course.name: Liberalism and Religion
course.description: A study of secular theories that examine the role of religion in the public square.

course.name: International Security
course.description: Strategic theory, terrorism, counterterrorism, military intervention, and intelligence in the contemporary world.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Upper-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Upper-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Democratization and Human Rights
course.description: A study of the theoretical underpinnings of democracy and the origins and development of human rights in the world today.

course.name: International Relations Theory
course.description: Traditional and modern international relations theories such as realism, idealism, and postmodernism.

course.name: Constitutional Law I
course.description: A study of the constitutional structure of government as developed by the U.S. Supreme Court relating to federalism, the separation of powers, the jurisdiction of the courts, the taxing power, the war power, and the commerce power.

course.name: Constitutional Law II
course.description: A study of the constitutional doctrines relating to civil rights and civil liberties such as First Amendment freedoms, equal protection, privacy, and rights of the accused.

course.name: Politics and Religion
course.description: An examination of the interaction between politics and religion in domestic and international politics.

course.name: Political Science Internship (repeatable Up to 6)
course.description: Individually designed study which permits the upper-level student to learn through participation in actual government settings, either domestic or international. Close consultation with the department in the design of this study will be necessary to conform to University standards regarding internships.

course.description: All courses and their applications must be defined and approved prior to registering.

course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.description: Individual research under the guidance of a faculty member(s).

course.description: To be used at the discretion of the department.

course.name: Seminar in Political Theory
course.description: An intensive analysis of more major issues in political theory. This course may be repeated for credit.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Lower-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Introduction to Psychology
course.description: A survey of the various areas included in the field of psychology, using the bio-psycho-social and scientific approaches to understanding behavior.

course.name: Developmental Psychology
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Human development from the prenatal stage through older adulthood. Emphasis: emotional, social, physical, motor, and psychological development of the individual.

course.name: Survey of Exceptionalities
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Reciprocal credit: PSY 225. A study of emotional, learning, and behavioral characteristics of persons with exceptionalities examined from a theoretical and experimental point of view.

course.name: Learning in Diverse Classrooms
course.description: See SE 230 for course description.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Lower-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Recommended: MAT 114 . Basic statistical measures and concepts necessary to understand psychological literature, with application to the behavioral sciences with emphasis on experimental design.

course.name: Industrial Psychology
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. An overview of psychology in the work place, relating to motivation, personnel selection and training, leadership styles, and human relations.

course.name: Adolescent Psychology
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. A study of the individual during adolescent years with emphasis on the development of self-identity and the problems faced by the American adolescent.

course.name: History of Psychology
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. The development of psychology from its early beginnings to the present with emphasis upon the various schools of psychology and contributions of outstanding individuals.

course.name: Behavioral and Cognitive Theories of Learning
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Prominent theories of learning in the context in which they were originated, their influence upon contemporary psychological thought, and their present applications.

course.name: Abnormal Psychology
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Causes and types of abnormal phenomena, mental hygiene, and therapeutic methods.

course.name: Adult Psychology
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Late adolescence through late adulthood using the theoretical framework of the life-span with emphasis on physical, cognitive, social and emotional development.

course.name: Theories of Personality
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. An introduction to the various theoretical positions regarding the development of personality placed in a general context of psychological theory and related to the psychological adjustment of the individual.

course.name: Child Growth and Development
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Physical, cognitive, social and emotional growth of children from prenatal through adolescence. Emphasis on major theories of development, their significance and issues for teachers and other professionals who work with children.

course.name: Physiological Psychology
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. The physiological bases of behavior with emphasis upon the neural substrates and biochemical bases of behavior, the sensory functioning and response capabilities of the organism and the genetic determinants of behavior.

course.name: Health Psychology
course.description: Stress, its effects and how to deal with it will be studied from a conceptual and application basis. Related topics include smoking, obesity, hypertension, headaches, insomnia, type A behavior, gastrointestinal disorders, cancer, and diabetes.

course.name: Issues in Psychology and Religion
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Explores the relationship between psychology and religion. Topics include guilt, conscience, growth/maturity, the Church and mental health, and Christian counseling.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Special Studies
course.description: Upper-level group studies which do not appear in the regular departmental offerings.

course.name: Positive Psychology
course.description: Prerequisites: PSY 213 plus 6 additional hours from PSY, SOC, SW. Explores the theory of Positive Psychology and its principles of learned optimism and authentic mental health.

course.name: Advanced General Psychology
course.description: Prerequisite: 15 hours of PSY. An extensive and in-depth study of the field emphasizing current research, issues, and methodology. In-depth coverage of the major areas of psychology.

course.name: Experimental Psychology
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Theoretical and practical aspects of experimental psychology with emphasis on experimental designs and results, practical applications of theoretical concepts and principles using individual and class projects, research techniques, written reports of projects, and journal readings.

course.name: Psychological Assessment
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Suggested: PSY 311 and 317. Methods of evaluation of individuals, including Exceptionalities, and the nature of administration and interpretation of intelligence, interest, personality, achievement and aptitude tests.

course.name: Applied Research
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 311 and 412, Senior PSY major and Instructor Permission. Hands-on, group research on various topics that include synthesizing findings into a research paper.

course.name: Field Research Presentation
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 415 and Instructor Permission Research presentation experience at a professional conference building on and refining the experiences and findings of PSY 415.

course.name: Social Psychology
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213 or SOC 211. Reciprocal credit: SOC 418. Factors which underlie the development of social behavior, social aspects of personality development and interaction between the individual and groups.

course.name: Sport Psychology
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Reciprocal credit: PEWS 421. See PEWS 421 for description.

course.name: Introduction to Counseling
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213, 317, or consent of the instructor. An introduction to the field of counseling. Various approaches will be studied, as well as job opportunities and the history of the counseling relationship itself. Supervised practice is a part of the course requirements.

course.name: Contemporary Issues in the Family
course.description: Reciprocal credit: SOC 435. See SOC 435 for description.

course.name: External Domestic Study Programs
course.description: All courses and their applications must be defined and approved prior to registering.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Practicum
course.description: Prerequisites: PSY 213, 317, 12 additional PSY hours, and prior approval. Field experience in a community agency. A journal and research paper are required. Purchase of professional liability insurance is required.

course.name: Independent Study
course.description: Individual research under the guidance of a faculty member(s).

course.name: Independent Study
course.description: Individual research under the guidance of a faculty member(s).

course.name: Seminar
course.description: To be used at the discretion of the department for majors only.

course.name: Seminar
course.description: To be used at the discretion of the department for majors only.

course.name: Scientific Reasoning
course.description: This course introduces students to the basic processes and dimensions of thinking involved in science through the exploration of varying topics in modern science. Examples of various main branches of science will be employed to examine how science contributes to problem-solving.

course.name: Environmental Science
course.description: This course provides a basic introduction to environmental science focusing on ecosystems including air, water, and soil. The course will deal with issues of sustainability, environmental justice and resource management.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Survey of Exceptionalities
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Reciprocal credit: PSY 225. A study of emotional, learning, and behavioral characteristics of persons with exceptionalities examined from a theoretical and experimental point of view.

course.name: Learning in Diverse Classrooms
course.description: Prerequisite: PSY 213. Reciprocal credit: PSY 230 Students will explore special education legislation regarding the rights of persons with disabilities and the effect on our educational system and society. The types of exceptionalities and the physical, mental, emotional, and social traits of individuals with disabilities will be explored as well as effective strategies for meeting their needs. Consideration will be given to major current problems and issues concerning persons with disabilities and those with learning differences. The class will guide students into developing a model for appropriate interaction with persons with disabilities informed by Christian values and ethics. Ten-hour field experience required.

course.name: Study Abroad Programs
course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Literacy for Special Populations
course.description: Students will explore the differences and understand how to meet the needs of diverse individuals in the areas of reading, writing, speaking, listening, and thinking. Students will develop a sensitive and reflective manner of meeting the needs of diverse pupils through the use of a variety of curricular and learning strategies, techniques, and adaptations. This course is taught as a part of a year-long internship and provides students with opportunities to engage in experiential learning.

course.name: Math/Science/Social Studies for Special Populations
course.description: Students will explore the content, materials, and methods of mathematics, science, and social studies teaching with special attention given to meeting the needs of persons with disabilities. Students will be encouraged to reflect upon best practices of teaching mathematics, science, and social studies while maintaining a sensitivity to individual differences. This course is taught as a part of a year-long internship and provides students with opportunities to engage in experiential learning.

course.name: Meeting the Needs of Severe & Profound Populations
course.description: Students will explore the content, materials, and methods of teaching students with significant academic and social behavior problems. Students will be encouraged to reflect upon best practices of teaching while maintaining sensitivity to individual differences. Ten-hour field experience required.

course.name: Teaching Math for Special Populations
course.description: The conceptual framework, which supports the Teacher Education Program at Union University, is A Teacher-Student Dynamic of Sensitivity, Reflection, and Faith.'' Within this framework this course provides an exploration of the content, materials, and methods of mathematics with special attention given to meeting the needs of students with disabilities. An emphasis on the discovery of mathematics and the understanding of mathematics will be explored. Students will be encouraged to reflect upon best practices of teaching mathematics while maintaining a sensitivity to individual differences. The class will guide students into developing a model for effective teaching and management informed by Christian values and ethics.

course.name: Seminar in Literacy for Special Education
course.description: The conceptual framework that supports the Teacher Education Program at Union University is a Teacher-Student Dynamic of Sensitivity, Reflection, and Faith.'' The central focus of this literacy seminar is on cultivating a reflective disposition in teacher candidates that is sensitive to the needs of students with mild to moderate disabilities in the areas of reading, listening, and viewing. It will also prepare teacher candidates to match identified literacy goals with the strategies, materials, and support that will enable all students to construct meaning from print and nonprint texts. This course complements EDU 331/630 - Literacy in Diverse Classrooms.

course.name: Characteristics and Needs of Pupils With Exceptionalities I
course.description: Prerequisite: SE 225 and EPP Admission. Trends for educational and psychological classifications, as well as the needs, the law, mainstreaming, and the emotional and behavioral characteristics with respect to individuals with exceptionalities will be explored. Includes field experience.

course.name: Characteristics and Needs of Pupils With Exceptionalities II
course.description: Prerequisite: SE 230 and EPP Admission. Emotional behavioral characteristics, assessment, and intervention strategies and theories are examined. Education of individuals with severe and profound handicaps is studied in relation to current trends and legislation. Includes field experience.

course.name: Tchg Persp/Pract Severe Handic
course.description: Prerequisite: SE 332 and TEP Admission. Perspectives and practices for teachers of individuals with severe and profound handicaps, including practices related to integration, communication, socialization, and transition. Personal living, vocational skills and maintenance training are included.

course.name: Tchg Indiv With Severe Handicp
course.description: Prerequisites: SE 332, 343, and TEP Admission. Teaching and training in the curricular areas for individuals with severe and profound handicaps including special and adaptive equipment, techniques and materials, and 25 hours of field experience.

course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Special Studies in Special Edu
course.description: Upper-level group studies which do not appear in the regular department offerings.

course.name: Educational Assessment of Students With Exceptionalities
course.description: Terms and constructs used in describing and interpreting test results will be studied with the uses, purposes, nature, and procedures of formal and informal tests. A brief history of psychometric testing will be presented. The student will be able to transform the assessment data into programmatic guidelines for instructional objectives. This course is taught as a part of a year-long internship and provides students with opportunities to engage in experiential learning.

course.description: All courses and their application must be defined and approved prior to travel.

course.name: Departmental Independent Study

course.name: Introduction to American Sign Language
course.description: Fundamentals of American Sign Language (ASL) including syntax, semantics, and pragmatics of signing as well as an introduction to deaf culture. These courses do not satisfy the core curriculum language requirement or any humanities requirement.

course.description: Fundamentals of American Sign Language (ASL) including syntax, semantics, and pragmatics of signing as well as an introduction to deaf culture. These courses do not satisfy the core curriculum language requirement or any humanities requirement.
